div.p: THE ROD OF RECOMPENCE OR THE HAND OF JUSTICE.
In the Puniſhment of the ENEMIES of CHURCH & STATE, BY Gods Providence and Juſtice brought about, after they had by the ſpace of eighteen years afflicted and tormented both.
Written by JOHN CONSET, D. in Phyſick.

q.p: The Lord is known to execute Judgement, and the wicked ſhall be trapped in the work of his own hands.
For the poor ſhall not alway be forgotten, the patient abiding of the meek ſhall not periſh for ever.
For when he maketh inquiſition for blood, he remembreth it, and forgetteth not the complaint of the poor.

div.p: London, Printed by T. R. for the Author, A. D. 1660.

div.head: THE ROD OF RECOMPENCE OR THE HAND OF JUSTICE.

lg.head: I
lg.l: THE branch which late I reached to the juſt,

l.hi: Of hap to thoſe who must

lg.l: Acknowledge Gods high power in Reſtauration,
Of them and theirs from this late deſolation.
Its meſſage ended, now becomes a rod
Of Recompence to thoſe, who man or God
Of late contemned, counting nothing holy
Which did not tend to th' advance of their folly.
Nor ſpar'd to ſcourge with inſolence the juſt,
And them to trample in the abject duſt.
Theſe Nimrods now by a moſt juſt ſucceſſion,
Muſt mount the ſcene to anſwer their oppreſſion.

lg.head: II.
lg.l: Thus have you ſeen the Providence divine

l.hi: And end their woes in fine

lg.l: Who did with patience kiſs their Soveraigns heſts,
Them daigning for a while (to be oppreſt)
Unto their Tyrant foes to give: But lo,
How he rewards their patience, and how
He crown'd their ſufferings with much conſolation,
And clears their innocence by this Reſtauration.

lg.head: III.
lg.l: Whilſt thoſe who late their ſtern oppreſſors were,
Benighted, and their horrid guilt loud cries
For vengeance on their retchleſs Butcheries
And Providence reads lectures of Inſtruction
To after-Ages; in their juſt deſtruction.

lg.head: IV.
lg.l: Not long it is ſince the black lines of woe,
Thoſe radiant Beams of Royal Majeſty,
Which erſt enlighten'd faithfull loyalty:
As Phaebus fills the leſſer ſtars with light,
Whoſe ſole Ecclipſe benights their glory bright.

lg.head: V.
lg.l: But now the radiant beams from Gods high favour,
To King and people) thoſe black lines out-raced,
Their comely viſage which had ſo defaced;
And brings on th' Scene their active cruel foe,
Which thus had drawn on them theſe lines of woe.

lg.head: VI
lg.l: Not long it is ſince theſe black ſons of errour

l.hi: And to juſt men a terror

lg.l: Mounted on their uſurped Throne did ſhine
With rayes of Pomp and Triumph; But in fine
Their luſtre proves like that which doth proceed
From thoſe falſe fires which miſts and vapors feed.

lg.head: VII.
lg.l: Mean while theſe meteors daily breath out woe,

l.hi: Who in their tract to go

lg.l: Refuſe; and therefore cruel ſervitude,
Or vaſſa lage to them they do conclude.
Nay death and Martyrdome muſt be their end,
Who to their rage will not aſſiſtance lend.

lg.head: VIII.
lg.l: But now behold theſe Titans brought to thrall
The ſpleen and envy of theſe Tyrants fell,
Who now muſt change their Throne into a cell:
Their Triumphs into Dirges muſt they turn,
And thoſe who long have laught, muſt learn to mourn
From whence they came, to that they muſt return.

lg.head: IX.
lg.l: Like Inſects they from corrupt matter came,
Muſt they diſſolve like thoſe Aegyptian flies,
Bred but to plague our Countrey for its vice:
But through repentance God hath them remanded,
Back to their cells again, when th' judgement's ended

lg.head: X.
lg.l: Their threas muſt they into petitions change,
(When others torments ſtrange
Enforc'd to ſue for mercy) their Petition;
And charg'd them (Loyal) with ſome foul ſedition.
Steeling their faces with harſh lines of Terrour,
Miſcalling truth with Epithites of errour;
Their Terrours turn'd into contempt and ſcorn.

lg.head: XI.
lg.l: Theſe are the men who truſted not in God,
And rather choſe ſins pleaſures for a ſeaſon,
Might their enjoyments be, though haughty treaſon
'Gainſt God and man the ſame conferr'd, than dure
Affliction with Gods people, who abjure

lg.head: XII.
lg.l: That gain or pleaſure which with Gods beheſt

l.hi: What to their ſouls ſeems beſt

lg.l: Do chuſe it, though clag'd with clods of affliction,
Or vail'd and ſhadow'd with clouds of dejection.
For well they know, that to their preſent grief
Joy ſhall ſucceed, and they ſhall find relief.

lg.head: XIII.
lg.l: But theſe, believe not God for future good
And wholly bend their thoughts that to attain
(Gods heſts neglecting) make their God their gain,
To which they ſacrifice their whole endeavour,
And by this homage from their Maker ſever,
Only in word they'l own Him; but in deed,
Their own devices, not his word, they'l creed.

lg.head: XIV.
lg.l: They ſpar'd no ill to bring about their end,
They wallow in all worldly joyes, and ſtill
(As if no God there were) their Genius fill
With all delights; Gods Word they only uſ'd
As ſervant to their luſts, thus it th' abuſed.

lg.head: XV.
lg.l: And ſith they ſaw no Judgement them ore take,

l.hi: A Rule for us to make

lg.l: Our Guide to holy life, they laid aſide,
And their ſucceſs they make their only guide
To prove Gods approbation, but behold
Their Mediums bad, and their concluſion cold.

lg.head: XVI.
lg.l: Loe he who 'gainſt his Soveraigns life did plead,
He for his own life pleads, but is deny'd,
Sith at his inſtance our dear Soveraign dy'd.
He could not happy be while Charles did live,
Nor we, except to him his meed we give:
His paſſed ſweets muſt we repay with ſowre,
His Sunſhines turn'd to Tempeſts toſſing ſhowre.

lg.head: XVII.
lg.l: And he whoſe frothy Rethorick did move

l.hi: But ſhows of what they love.

lg.l: The ſilly ones (to ſecond his deſign)
Their Rings, their lives and all for to reſign
To his diſpoſal, lo now he wants breath,
Or words to plead, and ſave himſelf from death.

lg.head: XVIII.
lg.l: Full often hath this Miſcreant abuſed
Amongſt poor Mortals them to light into
The way of Peace, there did he chuſe to do
His Antick Pageants; making it a ſtage
Of Drollery to the profane phrantique age.
God thus permitting him uncurb'd to run
From ill to worſe, till th' height of ills he had done,
And laſt the Guardon af thoſe ills hath won.

lg.head: XIX.
lg.l: And thoſe who erſt in pomp and Triumph led
Their force is ſcatter'd, and their Armie's ſhaken,
For Gods juſt judgement hath them overtaken,
Their valours daunted, and their Crafts out-vi'd,
And their deſignes made void on every ſide.

lg.head: XX.
lg.l: For he who from his Throne beholdeth all,
Doth come to paſs, permits mans curſt invention
Sometimes to take effect, but with intention
When he his whole atchievement hath attain'd,
And th' ſumme of all his wicked hope hath gain'd,
To let him ſee his hand can quickly foil
His greateſt Fortreſs, and it give to ſpoil.

lg.head: XXI.
lg.l: When therefore you oppreſſion do behold

l.hi: Let not your faith be cold.

lg.l: But know who heaven, and earth, and all hath made,
(Though long he ſuffer) yet by him's ore ſwaid
The powers therein contain'd; and 'its He,
Who all Oppreſſours and un • uſt doth ſee,
And will in time their injuries repay,
Avenge their wrongs at laſt, though long he ſtay.

lg.head: XXII.
lg.l: Moſt true it is we had deſerv'd his ire
With haughty ſpirits ſpurning, and with ſcorn
Rejecting his commands; His patience worn
With our rebellious wanton carriage, turning
To wrath and fury, 'gainſt our vices burning.

lg.head: XXIII.
lg.l: Therefore he gave us to the Philiſtim
Who ſpoil'd our houſes, and our lands did take
To their poſſeſſions, and our Church did make
A Den for foxes, or for Owles a neſt.
Our ſelves their Captives whom they rob'd of reſt,
Our women from their pleaſant places they
Caſt out, and made our joyes become their prey.

lg.head: XXIV.
lg.l: Thus were we toyled with fell ſervitude,
And did remove from us his ſcourging hand,
When gain'd the end of his Afflictions, and
Reclaimed us from ſinning, then he throwes
Into the fire of vengeance theſe our foes;
Whom by ſucceſs he made a Rod to us,
Now burnes the ſame, our woes concluding thus.

lg.head: XXV.
lg.l: Let not therefore Gods patience you incite
For ſure you ſhall by wofull tryal find,
He all your wrongs will treaſure up in mind,
And at the length, he vengeance on your head
Will feirce repay, either alive or dead.

lg.head: XXVI.
lg.l: Now ſith, O Lord, thy juſtice doth thus ſure
In ſpite of ill relief to th' wronged flock,
Who flie to thee as their faiths ſureſt rock.
Let us beware how we do thee provoke,
To lay on us thy ſcourge, and fatal ſtroke.
And let's in faith and fear wait for thy favour,
That here and after thou mayſt be our Saviour.
